Fig. 10 Surface insights into MnOx-based catalysts containing metal oxides for the selective catalytic reduction of NOX with NH3 Dong Ho Kim Conceptualization Data curation Investigation Validation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a b Yeon Jae Park Investigation Validation a b Kwan-Young Lee Supervision b Heon Phil Ha Funding acquisition Project administration Supervision a ⁎ Dong Wook Kwon Conceptualization Methodology Validation Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Extreme Materials Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology, Seoul 02792, South Korea Extreme Materials Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology Seoul 02792 South Korea Extreme Materials Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology, Seoul, 02792, South Korea. b Department of Chemical & Biological Engineering, Korea University, Seoul 02841, South Korea Department of Chemical & Biological Engineering, Korea University Seoul 02841 South Korea Department of Chemical & Biological Engineering, Korea University, Seoul, 02841, South Korea. ⁎ Corresponding authors. The MnOx/TiO2-based NOX reduction catalyst showed moderate performance at low temperature and had the disadvantage of low N2 selectivity. Herein, the effect of Sm and Ce interactions on MnOx-based catalysts in selective catalytic reduction was investigated. Sm increased the redox properties of the MnOx catalyst and the ratio of Mn4+. Meanwhile, Ce enhanced the additional redox trait of the Sm-modified catalyst. When exposed to SO2/O2, Sm and Ce-modified MnOx not only suppressed performance degradation, but also increased N2 selectivity. Sm and Ce suppress the formation of N2O by inhibiting the formation of N2O4 intermediate species. Additionally, regardless of exposure to SO2/O2, Sm/Ce modified MnOx is an LH-ER mechanism (Langmuir-Hinshelwood and Eley-Rideal mechanism), but in the case of MnOx, it is suggested to be mainly an ER mechanism when exposed to SO2/O2. From these results, a strategy for improving the N2 selectivity/SCR performance of MnOx/TiO2-based catalysts with SO2 resistance was provided. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords MnOx NH3-SCR Mechanism NOX reduction N2 selectivity 1 Introduction Nitric oxides (NOX) cause environmental issues (acid rain, photochemical smog, ozone layer depletion, and especially a precursor of fine particles such as PM2.5), and severe human health issues, and are one of the major air pollutants [1–3]. To cope with these problems, selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) is the most effective process for removing NOX around the world. Commercial catalysts (e.g. V2O5-WO3/TiO2 or V2O5-MoO3/TiO2) exhibiting moderate NOX reduction ability at 300–400 °C have difficulty satisfying the strict NOX emission regulations in some applications (e.g. cement, steel, and other industries; sources of NOX emissions below 250 °C [4–6]). Therefore, research on NH3-SCR catalysts with low thermal energy is important to exhibit outstanding performance even at low temperatures. Generally, SCR reactions are presented as follows. (1) 4 NO + 4 NH 3 + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O (2) 2 N O 2 + 4 NH 3 + O 2 → 3 N 2 + 6 H 2 O (3) 4 NH 3 + 2 NO + 2 N O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O Reaction 1 is generally defined as standard SCR. It is stoichiometry equal to that of NO and NH3. Reaction 2 proceeds by NO2 in standard SCR, and reacts with NH3 in a ratio of 1:2. Reaction 3 is generally known as the so-called “Fast SCR reaction”. In a previous study, it was reported that the “Fast SCR” reaction proceeds faster than the “Standard SCR” reaction (at low temperature) [7]. Therefore, it is one of the main factors for showing excellent performance at low temperature. Notably, transition metal oxides (e.g., V, Fe, Cu, Mn) have been studied extensively for SCR reactions [8,9]. Among them, research on Mn oxide (MnOx) catalysts is being actively conducted to show outstanding low-temperature NOX reduction performance (below 300 °C) [8,10–12]. In addition, MnOx is used as a major active material in various catalytic redox reactions (e.g. NH3-SCR [13,14], CO oxidation [15,16], CH4 oxidation [17], oxygen evolution electrocatalysts [18] etc.) due to their excellent redox potential [19]. Of note, MnOx has a multivalent nature, which facilitates the redox ability of the catalysts [20]. Interestingly, the MnOx exhibits different catalyst properties depending on the stable oxides (typically, MnO2, Mn2O3, Mn3O4, MnO etc.) in NH3-SCR reactions according to supports, crystalline planes, morphologies, and preparation methods [21–23]. Specifically, it was suggested that the amount of oxygen species on the MnOx surface decreases from Mn4+ (MnO2) to Mn2+ (MnO), and MnO2 is extraordinarily beneficial to the redox properties of the catalyst. Accordingly, MnO2 shows the highest NOX reduction activity per unit surface area as a major active species [24]. In addition, the lattice oxygen of MnO2 participates in the activation process of the reaction gas. However, pure MnOx has two major problems in the SCR reaction. First, it has a narrow temperature range at a low temperature [25,26]. Specifically, the V2O5/TiO2 based catalyst shows low performance below 250 °C, but the MnOx/TiO2 based catalyst shows excellent performance even at ~200 ℃. However, it exhibited the properties of reducing NOX reduction and N2 selectivity due to oxidation reaction at 220 °C or higher, and performance decrease below 200 ℃ due to low thermal energy. Second, the critical problem of MnOx is its vulnerability to SO2 [27]. To overcome this problem, the affinity between Mn and SO2 (e.g., it forms MnSO4 that acts as inactive sites) is reduced by using a supporter (e.g., TiO2 etc.), or durability to SO2 is enhanced by adding a promoter. Meanwhile, until now, SO2 has been considered only as a deactivation source in the MnOx catalyst. However, SO2 species can bind with metals to form metal sulfate species (e.g., Ce(SO4)2) and act as active sites, providing additional acidic sites [28]. In the SCR reaction mechanism (e.g., Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) or Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism), NH3 and NO react at an acidic site (Lewis acidic site ( LA ), i.e., Mn+ (M; metal) or Brӧnsted acidic site ( BA , i.e., M(n−1)+-OH)) or redox site (Mn+=O) to form an intermediate species. Of note, the formed intermediate species (e.g., NH4NO3 or NH4NO2) is decomposed into N2 and H2O according to the reaction route, but there is a problem in that it is decomposed into N2O, which is a byproduct form, resulting in poor N2 selectivity. To improve N2 selectivity and NOX elimination, MnOx-modified catalysts containing transition metal (Co [29], Fe [30], etc.) or rare earth metals (Ce [31], Sm [32], Eu [33], etc.) as a promoter have been developed. For instance, Sm among rare earth metals not only promotes SO2 tolerance of Mn-Ce oxide by suppressing electron transfer (e.g., SO2 to Ce4+) [32], but also promotes the formation of intermediate species (nitrate species). Furthermore, Ce enhances the redox process of Mn (increases oxygen mobility) and inhibits the formation of ammonium (bi)sulfate (denoted as AS or ABS), thereby enhancing SO2 resistance. To avoid the low MnOx performance (or N2 selectivity) and resistance to SO2/O2 shown in the previous literature [14,34], Sm oxide and Ce oxide-introduced MnOx/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized. The enhanced redox traits and acidic properties of the catalysts introduced with Sm oxide and Ce oxide were more clearly explored and interpreted from the viewpoint of the reaction mechanism. Specifically, the amount of usable oxygen species (or oxygen species participating in the reaction) in the SCR reaction was confirmed by experimental and analytical techniques. In addition, the cause of the enhancement of performance and N2 selectivity was investigated by identifying intermediate species or NOX species adsorbed on the surface. From this point of view, this suggested the reaction mechanism at low and high temperatures of MnOx based catalysts. Additionally, the effects of Sm oxide and Ce oxide used to circumvent the effect on SO2/O2, known as the weakness of MnOx, were investigated. Overall, this study explored the causes of improved low-temperature performance and selectivity and the changed surface properties due to the introduction of Sm oxide and Ce oxide in MnOx-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All the MnOx-based catalysts on anatase TiO2 (DT-51, Cristal Global Co.) were prepared by coprecipitation or wet impregnation. Typically, 0.82 g of potassium permanganate (KMnO4, Sigma Aldrich Co., ≥ 99.0%) and 2.1 g of manganese (II) acetate tetrahydrate (Mn(CH3COO)2.4 H2O (MnAc2), Daejung Co., ≥ 98.0%) were used to adjust the Mn content to ~ 15 wt% were mixed with prepared anatase TiO2 in 200 mL of deionized water (D.I. water) at room temperature. The slurry was stirred at 300 rpm for 3 h. Then, the sediment was washed with D.I. water (2 L) for the removal of soluble ions. The filtered sample was dried overnight at 110 °C and calcined under air at 300 °C for 4 h with a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1. The calcined sample is denoted as ‘Mn’. The addition of Sm or SmCe for synthesizing MnSm and MnSmCe was prepared by the wet impregnation method. Samarium (Sm(NO3)3.6 H2O, samarium nitrate hexahydrate, Alfa Aesar, ≥ 99.9%) or cerium (Ce(NO3)3.6 H2O, cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate, Alfa Aesar, REacton®, ≥ 99.5%) precursors were dissolved in 50 mL of D. I. water. The aqueous solutions were added dropwise to prepared anatase TiO2 in 200 mL of D. I. water. The slurry was stirred for 3 h, subjected to rotary evaporation to eliminate residual water, dried overnight at 110 °C, and air calcined at 300 °C for 4 h with ramping rate of 10 °C min−1. Then, MnSm and MnSmCe catalysts were prepared in the same protocol except that Sm and SmCe were used instead of anatase TiO2 used to prepare ‘Mn’. The Mn-based catalysts were poisoned by exposing 500 ppm NOX, 500 ppm NH3, 100 ppm SO2, 6 vol% H2O, and 8 vol% O2 balanced by N2. The Mn-based catalysts were sulfite/sulfate treated with 100 ppm of SO2/N2 and 8 vol% O2/N2 at 300 °C for an hour and a total flow rate of 500 mL min−1 balanced by N2. The sulfite/sulfate catalysts were denoted as XXX-S, where XXX indicates MnOx/TiO2-based catalysts. 2.2 Reactions The catalytic NH3-SCR reaction was performed in a fixed bed quartz reactor with a inner and outer radii of 4 and 5 mm, respectively. The Mn-based catalysts were sieved to 300–425 µm and loaded (0.31 gCAT or 0.62 gCAT for gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60,000 hr−1 or 30,000 hr−1, respectively) in quartz reactor. The reactant gases were injected into the fixed bed quartz reactor using a mass flow controller (MFC, KOFLOC Co.) under the following conditions: 500 ppm NOX, NOX/NH3 = 1.0, 8 vol% O2, 6 vol% H2O balanced by N2, and a total flow rate of 500 mL min−1. All the injected gases and exhausted gas were monitored constantly using nondispersive infrared gas analyzers (NDIR) as follows: ZKJ (Fuji Electric Co.) for NO, Ultramat 6 (Fuji Electric Co.) for N2O, and a detector tube (GASTEC Co.) for quantifying NH3 or NO2 concentrations. The NOX (NO+NO2) conversion (X(NOx)) for NH3-SCR (or NH3 oxidation (XNH3)) was calculated by the following equations: (4) N O X conversion ( % ) = [ N O X ] I N − [ N O + N O 2 ] O U T [ N O X ] I N × 100 (5) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = [ N O X ] I N + [ N H 3 ] I N − [ N O ] O U T − [ N O 2 ] O U T − 2 [ N 2 O ] O U T − [ N H 3 ] O U T [ N O X ] I N + [ N H 3 ] I N − [ N O X ] O U T − [ N H 3 ] O U T × 100 (6) N H 3 conversion ( % ) = [ N H 3 ] I N − [ N H 3 ] O U T [ N H 3 ] I N × 100 The O2 on/off experiment was the same as the NH3-SCR reactions except for space velocity (60,000 hr−1 → 30,000 hr−1) and H2O-free conditions. The SO2 longevity experiment was the same as the NH3-SCR experiment except that 100 ppm of SO2 was injected. Unlike the NH3-SCR experiment, the kinetic experiment was performed with inner and outer radii of 3 and 5 mm, and the reaction conditions were the same. The NOX consumption rates were normalized to mass and surface area, and calculated below 25% NOX conversion considering the reaction limited regime. The NOX consumption rates were calculated using the following equation. − r NOX min - 1 = (7) moles of NO X per gram of catalyst and per unit time mol NOX g CAT − 1 min − 1 gram of catalyst ( mol NOX g CAT − 1 ) 2.3 Characterization The surface area of the MnOx/TiO2 based catalysts was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET; N2 physisorption) method after pretreatment under vacuum conditions at 180 °C for 3 h via NOVA 2200e (Quantachrome Co.). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of MnOx/TiO2 based catalysts were investigated via a D8 Advance diffractometer (Bruker Co.) by using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) with a 2θ range of 20 °− 80 °. The X-ray fluorescence (XRF) experiment was implemented by using A ZSX Primus II (Rigaku). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) with diffraction patterns was performed to confirm high resolution image and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns using a FEITitanTM 80–300 microscope operating at 300 kV. To confirm elemental mapping analysis, Super-X EDX was investigated via an FEI Talos F200X at 200 kV. The metal composition of the MnOx-based catalysts was investigated by a field emission transmission electron microscope with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (Bruker). The temperature programmed reduction profile using H2 (H2-TPR) was investigated by pretreating the catalysts at 300 °C for an hour in a 10 vol% O2/He flow environment, then cooling to 60 °C and inserting 10 vol% H2/Ar by increasing to 700 °C at 10 °C min−1. H2-TPR analysis was measured via Autochem 2950 (Micrometrics Co.). NH3/NO/O2 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD/NO-TPD/O2-TPD) was also performed via Autochem 2950. MnOx/TiO2-based samples were pretreated with 10 vol% O2/He for an hour at 300 °C and then cooled to 60 °C. Then, the catalyst was fully saturated with NH3 (or NO, O2) for an hour in 5 vol% NH3 (or NO, O2)/Ar, and purged with He for an hour to remove physically adsorbed NH3 (or NO, O2) on the catalyst surface. The NH3 (m/z = 17), NO/NO2 (m/z = 30/46), and O2 (m/z = 32) gas was desorbed at a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1 to 700 °C was monitored in succession via a QMS (quadrupole mass spectrometer; HPR20, Hiden Co.). X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra of the MnOx-based catalysts were investigated under the conditions of top-up mode, resolution, and storage current of 3 GeV, 0.2 eV, and 250 mA, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed with a microfocus monochromatic X-ray source of monochromatic AlKα (1486.6 eV) via Nexsa (Thermo Scientific Co.). The samples were dried at 100 °C for 18 hr and then analyzed at vacuum at 10−6 Pa, and the result was corrected on the peak of C 1 s (284.6 eV). The obtained peaks were deconvolved and fitted via the Lorentzian-Gaussian function method. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTs) analysis was investigated by using Nicolet iS20 (Thermo Co.) with diffuse reflectance (DR). After the samples are placed in an in-situ chamber where heating is possible, a reaction gas is injected at a specific temperature to react with the catalyst surface. Then, it is pretreated at 300 ℃ to remove impurities and moisture. The calcium fluoride (CaF2) window was used for the DR instrument, and the spectrum was profiled through a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was implemented by using a TGA2 (Mettler-Toledo Co.). Prior to analysis, the MnOx/TiO2-based catalysts were put into an Al2O3 pan, and then purged with N2 at 100 °C with a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1 for an hour. Then, the furnace was heated to 1000 °C under N2 with a ramping rate of 2 °C min−1 to obtain a profile for weight loss (wt%) versus temperature (°C). The MASS profile of the gas emitted during TGA analysis was confirmed via a QMS (quadrupole mass spectrometer; HPR20, Hiden Co.). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of the catalysts The SCR performance (X(NOx)) and N2 selectivity (S(N2)) of MnOx-based catalysts were investigated. As shown in Fig. S1, the NH3-SCR performance of MnOx-based catalysts was evaluated according to the content of Sm which is one of the rare earth metals with moderate redox properties. As a result, X(NOx) showed ~100% at ~200 °C, and all catalysts in which Sm was synthesized showed performance improvement at low and high temperatures. Among them, 15Mn/3Sm/TiO2 (further denoted MnSm) containing 3 wt% Sm showed excellent NH3-SCR performance. In addition, it was confirmed that S(N2) was improved compared to Mn. Notably, MnSm exhibited an X(NOx) enhancement of approximately 15% at 120 °C, and an enhanced S(N2) of approximately 40% at 300 °C. As shown in Fig. 1, Ce, another rare earth metal reported to have excellent redox properties in the SCR reaction [35,36], was synthesized with Mn to confirm the NH3-SCR performance. At 120 °C, among the catalysts in which Ce was synthesized, 15Mn/3Sm-5Ce/TiO2 showed an X(NOx) enhancement of approximately 10% compared to MnSm. Considering the characteristics of the promoter (Sm or Ce) content of MnOx based catalysts, Sm plays a role in improving the SCR performance of Mn at low temperatures and N2 selectivity at high temperatures. MnSm with an optimal Sm content, which will be mentioned later, was named MnSm, and 15Mn/3Sm-XCe/TiO2 (where X is the content of Ce) was named MnSmXCe. 3.2 Structural properties of the catalysts The dispersion of active metal on TiO2 and the morphology of MnOx-based catalysts were confirmed by XRD analysis, and the results are shown in Fig. 2A. Except for MnSm10Ce, only the anatase peak of tetragonal TiO2 (JCPDF No. 01–084–1285) was observed for MnSmXCe (X = 3 or 5). This implied that the active metals are highly dispersed on TiO2. Meanwhile, bulk CeO2 (JCPDF No. of 00–001–0800) was observed due to aggregation of excess CeO2 on TiO2 in MnSm10Ce. As shown in Fig. 2, Mn, MnSm and MnSm5Ce were selected to compare the morphological characteristics by the synthesis of Sm and Ce, and the morphological features were verified by HR-TEM analysis. As seen from the HR-TEM image, only TiO2 anatase morphology was observed, and the particle size of all catalysts showed a similar trend of ~ 30 nm. This was confirmed to be consistent with the XRD results (in Fig. 2B, 2D, and 2 F). On the other hand, the surface area, one of the textural properties of the catalyst, is a factor that could partially confirm the correlation with the dispersion of the catalyst. When Sm and Ce were introduced into Mn, the surface area was slightly increased. This suggested that some Mn clusters are highly dispersed by Sm and Ce. However, in the case of MnSmCe, some surface areas might be reduced due to agglomeration caused by the bulk formation of Ce oxide. EDX mapping of each catalyst was investigated to confirm additional catalyst dispersion, and the results are shown in Fig. S2. Mn was found to be partially dispersed on the TiO2 surface. In the MnSm catalyst, Mn element (yellow) was partially dispersed similarly to Mn, and interestingly, it was confirmed to exist in a position similar to that of Sm. It is highly suggested that Sm and Mn interact with each other. Meanwhile, it was confirmed that MnSm5Ce in which Ce was synthesized highly dispersed Mn and Sm on the TiO2 surface, unlike Mn and MnSm. These results suggest that Ce plays a role in dispersing the metal oxide present on the TiO2 surface. In general, it is reported that the highly dispersed metal oxide on TiO2 helps as an active site [37]. In addition, the structural characteristics (surface facet) of the metal oxide contained in each of the catalysts confirmed by HRTEM can be confirmed by the SAED pattern shown in Fig. 2C, E, and G. Equally, the (101) and (004) facets of tetragonal TiO2 with ~3.5 Å and ~2.4 Å were identified in all catalysts, and the facets of ~3.1 Å (110) and ~2.7 Å (222), MnO2 (JCPDF No. of 00–001–0799) and Mn2O3 (JCPDF No. of 00–001–1061) were identified, respectively. This result suggests that Mn oxide exists in various metal oxide forms on the TiO2 surface. On the other hand, the Sm2O3 (400) facet (~2.7 Å) and SmO (111) facet (~2.9 Å) were observed at MnSm (in Fig. 2E), and (002) facet of Ce2O3 (~6.1 Å) and CeO2 (111) facet (3.1 Å) were observed at MnSm5Ce. The results of all SAED pattern analyses suggested that metal oxides dispersed on TiO2 exist in various oxide forms. 3.3 Redox properties of the catalysts The redox properties were first investigated using H2-TPR, which explored the oxidation state and reduction ability of metal oxides as shown in Fig. 3 A. The amount of reducible oxygen species in each catalyst can be calculated through the area of the H2-TPR analogues. The results of H2 consumption of the MnOx-based catalyst are shown in Table S1. The addition of Sm and Ce resulted in an increase in the amount of reducible oxygen source of the bulk catalyst, and an increase in the amount of Ce showed a tendency to increase the amount of total H2 consumption. For MnOx based catalysts, peaks were observed in three regions. It is divided into approximately 300 °C (MnO2 to Mn2O3), 300–400 ℃ (Mn2O3 to Mn3O4), and above 450 ℃ (Mn3O4 to MnO). The peak that increases near 500 ℃ is caused by (1) SmO2 → Sm2O3 reduction and (2) Ce-O-Sm, which appears due to the interaction between CeO2 and Sm2O3 [2]. As mentioned in the introduction section, MnO2 species (at approximately 300 °C) exhibited the redox properties of the SCR reaction. The addition of Sm and Ce showed a tendency to shift the reduction peak of MnO2 to low temperature, and MnSm5Ce exhibited the lowest peak temperature of MnO2 among the Mn based catalysts. In other words, MnSm5Ce has the ability to reduce oxygen even with low thermal energy, meaning that oxygen can be used more easily than other catalysts. Overall, it was suggested that MnSm5Ce, which has a moderate H2 consumption amount (46.4 mmolH2 gCAT −1) and the highest reducibility (~ 256 °C peak temperature), has outstanding redox ability. In catalysis, the type of oxygen is very important. To investigate the type/ratio of oxygen originating from surface oxygen species, the O 1 s region was explored via XPS analysis as shown in Fig. 3B. The peak was deconvoluted into three regions, which were assigned to oxygen derived from lattice oxygen (Oβ), surface-chemisorbed oxygen (Oα), and oxygen originating from chemisorbed H2O (O′α) located at 529.6 eV, 530.5 eV, and 531.5 eV, respectively [38]. Of note, Oα species have excellent oxygen mobility compared to lattice oxygen (Oβ) and are known to be easily used for oxidation reactions. In addition, it was used as an oxygen source for the NO to NO2 oxidation reaction, and could provide NO2 used for “Fast SCR” reaction at low temperature. While Mn possessed Oα species of approximately 17%, it was confirmed that the MnOx-based catalyst with added Sm and Ce had an Oα ratio of 20% or more. Specifically, MnSm5Ce exhibited 35.1% of Oα ratio among the total oxygen species. In H2-TPR, the peak temperature of MnO2 species coincided with the trend of the lowest temperature and the trend of the Oα ratio. That is, MnSm5Ce seems to have excellent oxygen mobility and redox traits that could easily use oxygen species. In MnOx-based catalysts, NO species that adsorb to the redox site ([Mnn+=O], n = 2, 3, or 4) are activated into various forms of nitrite/nitrate (mono-, bi-, or bridged-NO2 - or NO3 - etc.). The adsorbed nitrite/nitrate reacts with NH3 to form an intermediate species, and the reaction cycle proceeds. Labile oxygen (surface-chemisorbed oxygen), which is mainly used in SCR reactions, is considered very important in reactions that proceed with the redox cycle [39]. Therefore, to confirm the redox cyclability during the reaction, an O2 on/off experiment was performed ( Fig. 4). To equalize the amount of saturated oxygen species in the condition in which the initial excess O2 is injected (8 vol% of O2), it was measured at a space velocity different from the SCR performance experiment (60,000 hr−1 → 30,000 hr−1). Additionally, to clearly confirm the recyclability of O2, H2O injection was excluded because of the inhibition effect on SCR reactions. To distinguish the role of each metal, three catalysts, Mn, MnSm, and MnSm5Ce, were compared at 120 °C with a clear performance difference. The N2 selectivity was maintained above 98% for all catalysts during the reaction (not shown). This is suggested to be due to the additional NOX reduction by reacting the adsorbed nitrate species with NH3 according to the increased catalyst amount. After an hour, gaseous O2 injection was stopped for 3 hr. This means that only surface adsorbed oxygen species and lattice oxygen near the surface can be used except for gaseous oxygen (oxygen species in the redox site of the catalysts). As mentioned above, at this time, oxygen species (Mn+=O) at the redox site react with NO in the gas phase to form NO2 -/NO3 -, and oxygen vacancies. In Fig. 4A, all catalysts showed a decrease in performance after O2 injection was shut off from the gas stream. This appears to be a phenomenon that occurs when the gaseous oxygen supply is shut off, and the reacting gaseous O2 does not intervene in the reaction. Notably, the decrease in X(NOx) of each catalyst was measured differently. This might depend on the ability of the catalyst to use oxygen species (active oxygen). Although the initial performance of MnOx based catalysts was the same (X(NOx) ~ 100%), after 3 h of O2 injection was shut off, Mn, MnSm, and MnSm5Ce showed X(NOx) of ~43%, ~46%, and ~62%, respectively. While the performance decreases, the decreasing performance shows how well the surface (or lattice oxygen near the surface) oxygen source is utilized. Additionally, this result suggested that X(NOx) after O2-free conditions for 3 h was due to the amount of oxygen species in the catalyst (e.g., chemisorbed surface oxygen (Oα) or oxygen located in the oxygen vacancy on the surface). Meanwhile, O2-TPD analysis was performed as a method to confirm the oxygen species usability of the catalyst (Fig. S3). Of note, an important factor in the redox cycle of the SCR reaction cycle is the ability to use the O2 inherent in the catalyst [40]. As a result, it was confirmed that the amount of O2 desorption was increased in MnSm and MnSm5Ce compared to Mn. (Mn; 73.3 μmolO2g−1 CAT, MnSm; 110.8 μmolO2g−1 CAT, MnSm5Ce; 123.0 μmolO2g−1 CAT) Importantly, the amount of O2 desorption of the catalyst can indicate the amount of oxygen species that can be used by the catalyst, and the amount of O2 inherent in the catalyst means the ability to use O2 required for the SCR reaction. As a result, the introduction of Sm increases usable oxygen species in the catalyst, showing that the introduction of Ce plays a role in further enhancing the oxygen usable ability. Indeed, it is confirmed that MnSm5Ce is excellent in the oxygen species usable ability during the SCR reaction among the MnOx based catalysts, which was in-line with the results of H2-TPR, O2-TPD, and the Oα ratio of the O 1 s regime (via XPS analysis). Additionally, the redox characteristics and chemical state of the surface metal composition were confirmed via XPS analysis as shown in Fig. 5. On the surface of the metal composition supported on TiO2, defect sites might be formed during the synthesis process, and the valence state would be changed by electron transfer between the metals. Mn acting as the main active site was deconvoluted as Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+ species in the Mn 2p 3/2 region by Gaussian-Lorentzian fitting, and was located at binding energies of 640.6 eV, 641.7 eV, and 642.8 eV, respectively [41]. Of note, as mentioned in the introduction, it has been reported that Mn4+ (MnO2) species not only activate the redox cycle using gaseous oxygen, but also show excellent NOX reduction performance per unit area [42,43]. Therefore, the ratio of Mn4+ to the total oxidation relative (blue circle) is shown in Fig. 5A. Interestingly, among the MnOx based catalysts, MnSm5Ce showed the highest ratio (~70.2%) of Mn4+ species. Importantly, compared to the Mn4+ ratio of Mn, MnSm or MnSm5Ce showed higher Mn4+ species. It is suggested that Sm and Ce (or between Sm and Ce) exhibit redox by electron transfer with Mn. Meanwhile, on the catalyst surface, the added metal oxides might interact with Mn. First, to confirm the redox trait of Sm, the peak of the Sm 3d 3/2 region of the MnSm based catalyst was deconvoluted, as shown in Fig. 5B. The binding energy of Sm 3d represents ~1106 eV of Sm 3d 3/2, and Sm2+ and Sm3+ of 1105.2 eV and 1108.3 eV were deconvoluted, respectively [44]. Of note, in the case of MnSm, Sm2+/(Sm2++Sm3+) showed ~60.7%. This suggested that some Sm3+ species are formed by the redox cycle as ‘Sm3+ + Mn3+ ↔ Sm2+ + Mn4+’. Specifically, Mn has a Mn4+ ratio of 40.1%, while MnSm has a Mn4+ ratio of 49.4%. This could verify the redox cycle in which the addition of Sm promotes the formation of Mn4+. Additionally, the MnSm-based catalyst was compared in the Ce- added catalysts. As mentioned above, it can be seen that the oxidation state of Mn is changed by the addition of Sm and Ce. Notably, MnSm5Ce was confirmed to have a Sm2+ ratio of 74.5% among the catalysts to which Ce was added. Meanwhile, MnSm10Ce has a Sm2+ ratio of 53%. This suggested that the introduction of a large amount of Ce affects the oxidation state of Sm (i.e., increases in Sm3+). To confirm the oxidation state of Ce, the Ce 3d region was investigated as shown in Fig. 5C. The Ce 3d region is classified into V and U, which correspond to the spin-orbit split of two types of Ce 3d 5/2 and 3d 3/2 core holes [41,45]. Notably, among the catalysts to which Ce was added, MnSm5Ce was confirmed to have a Sm2+ ratio of 74.5%. On the other hand, MnSm10Ce has an Sm2+ ratio of 53%. This suggested that the addition of a large amount of Ce affects the valence state of Sm (increases in Sm3+). Therefore, in order to confirm the valence state of Ce, the Ce 3d region was investigated as shown in Fig. 5C. The peaks of V0, V2, U0, and U2 correspond to Ce3+, and are assigned to binding energies of 880.5 eV, 885.3 eV, 899 eV, and 904.8 eV, respectively. V1, V3, V4, U1, U3, and U4 correspond to Ce4+ and are assigned at 882.5 eV, 888 eV, 898.3 eV, 901.1 eV, 907.5 eV, and 916.6 eV, respectively [41,45]. Interestingly, it is proposed that the additional addition of Ce to MnSm affects the oxidation states of Mn. Specifically, the introduction of Ce affected the interaction with Mn. (Ce3+ + Mn4+ ↔ Ce4+ + Mn3+) MnSm5Ce showed the highest ratio of Ce3+ (42.5%) among the MnSmCe catalysts. The Ce3+ species on the surface usually coexist with surface oxygen vacancies, which can increase the chemisorbed O* and dissociation of NO molecules, promoting the NH3-SCR performance [46–48]. Interestingly, MnSm3Ce and MnSm10Ce showed similar ratios of Ce3+. However, it was confirmed that the ratio of Sm2+ of MnSm3Ce and MnSm10Ce is somewhat different. This result suggested that the ratio of Mn4+ and Sm2+ was significantly decreased because the absolute amount of Ce4+ species is high in MnSm10Ce. These results suggested a role for Sm and Ce. Sm2+ species play a role in increasing the amount of Mn4+ species (via Sm3+ + Mn3+ ↔ Sm2+ + Mn4+), and Ce3+ species enhance Mn4+ and increase electrons via ‘Mn4+ + Ce3+ ↔ Mn3+ + Ce4+’. Additionally, X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) analysis was performed to confirm the bulk redox properties of the catalysts. The normalized absorption XANES spectra of the Mn L 3,2-edge for manganese oxide reference materials and MnOx-based catalysts are shown in Fig. 6. Because of a quadruple transition from the 3d orbital, the XANES spectra present a weak pre-edge trait. The oxidation state of Mn is confirmed to be a mixture of 3+ to 4+ . First, MnO2 and Mn2O3 reference materials were measured to confirm the location (eV) according to the oxidation state of each sample. Here, the XANES spectra intensity of the MnOx based catalyst is related to the Mn 2p → 3d transition and is related to the density of the Mn 3d [49]. It was confirmed that the introduction of Sm and Ce compared to Mn not only increased the density of Mn species of MnO2/Mn2O3 species, but also increased the amount of bulk Mn4+ species acting as major active sites. The analogues of the MnOx/TiO2 based catalyst seem to be mixed with Mn4+/Mn3+, but it is confirmed that they are mainly present as Mn4+ (MnO2). This showed a partially in-line result from the XPS analysis. Overall, the tendency of the introduction of Ce to increase the amount of Mn4+ species showed in-line results, but in the case of MnSm5Ce, a tendency to expose a large amount of Mn4+ to the surface/bulk was confirmed (enlarged data in Fig. 6). As a result, Ce/Sm increases the amount of bulk MnO2 species, suggesting that a certain Ce content (MnSm5Ce) plays a role in dispersing Mn4+ on the catalyst surface/bulk. 3.4 Acidic properties of the catalysts In general, the SCR reaction is initiated through the adsorption and activation of NH3 [50,51]. The adsorption amount and adsorbed species (acidic properties) of NH3 via NH3-TPD are shown in Fig. S4. The NH3 desorption profiles of each catalyst were measured in different analogues, and these were confirmed after saturating NH3 at 60 °C and serving thermal energy up to 700 °C. The NH3 area was classified into two sites at 200 °C. Mn showed a gradually decreasing analog based on the maximum peak below 200 °C, whereas the introduction of Sm and Ce increased the desorption area up to 700 °C, particularly, showing an additional increase in the area of additional acidic sites above 200 °C. This indicates an increase in strongly adsorbed NH3 species, with an increase in the amount of relatively unstable (weakly) adsorbed species. This shows that it not only increases the NH3 adsorption ability at low temperature (below 200 °C), but also increases the NH3 adsorption capacity at high temperature at approximately 250 °C or higher. Here, the amount of desorbed ammonia (ammonia adsorption amount) is shown in Table. S1. Similar to the redox property results, it was confirmed that the amount of adsorbed NH3 increased with the addition of Sm and Ce, and the number of acidic sites was increased. It seems that the introduction of Sm and Ce is related to the increase in Mn4+ serving as the major active site as an additional NH3 adsorption site. The adsorption enhancement at low temperature not only provides an additional site for interaction with NOX (gaseous or adsorbed NOX) and gaseous O2 on the surface of catalysts, but also suggests that NH3 could maintain binding with the surface even at high surface thermal energy. Interestingly, the introduction of Sm only increased strong NH3 adsorption above 200 °C. This suggested an increased chance for NH3 to react at high temperatures (above 200 °C). Significantly, the introduction of additional Ce not only enhanced the amount of weakly bound NH3 species below 200 °C, but also enhanced the amount of adsorbable NH3 species at temperatures above 200 °C. In the previous studies, it was reported that the NH3 peak observed at 200 °C or lower was attributed to the Brӧnsted acidic site (BA), which increased the reactivity of NH3 and NOX at low temperature [40]. Notably, MnSm10Ce was confirmed to have the highest NH3 adsorption amount among the MnOx-based catalysts. Therefore, it is suggested that increasing the Ce content in MnOx based catalysts might provide additional acidic sites. However, it is confirmed that the introduction of more than a certain amount of Ce (i.e., 10 wt% of Ce) does not significantly affect the additional performance enhancement for NH3 desorption amount. As shown in Fig. 3A-B, TMAX was observed at the lowest temperature in MnSm5Ce, the optimal catalyst (reducibility via H2-TPR), and it was confirmed that it had the highest ratio of Oα species. That is, the Sm-Ce modified MnOx/TiO2 based catalyst shows that the redox property can act as an important factor in the presence of a certain amount of NH3 adsorption. Meanwhile, it was collected using background subtracted in-situ DRIFT spectra to confirm the nature of the adsorption between the catalyst surface and the reactants (NO, O2, and NH3). In Fig. 7, the interaction with the reaction gas at 120 °C showing a distinct performance difference at low temperature was confirmed using Mn, MnSm, and MnSm5Ce catalysts. The in-situ DRIFT spectra of the catalyst were illustrated in the order of 30 min of NO/O2 adsorption, 30 min of NH3 adsorption, and 30 min of NO/O2 adsorption again (Fig. 7A-7C; Mn, Fig. 7D-7F; MnSm, Fig. 7G-7I; MnSm5Ce). This was profiled to explain the reaction mechanism and the identification of adsorbed species formed when NO/O2 and NH3 are adsorbed on the catalyst surface. When NO/O2 was adsorbed to each catalyst, 1620, 1607, 1587, 1532, 1513, 1488, 1290, 1246, and 1388 cm−1 were observed as shown in Figs. 7A, 7D, and 7 G. The band at 1620 cm−1 was attributed to the asymmetric vibration of gaseous NO2 [2]. The bands at 1607 and 1587 cm−1 could be assigned to bidentate nitrate (NO3 -), 1532 and 1513 cm−1 were attributed to monodentate nitrate (NO3 -), 1388 cm−1 was assigned to M=NO2 (M= Mn, Sm, or Ce) species [52], and ~1488, 1290, 1246 cm−1 were linear nitrite (NO2 -), chelating nitrite (NO2 -), and bridging nitrate (NO3 -), respectively [2,14,53]. It was confirmed that the addition of Sm and Ce increased the intensity of NO2 -/NO3 -. This was confirmed to be similar to the trend of NO-TPD, as shown in Fig. S5. In other words, MnSm and MnSm5Ce appear to enhance the affinity between the catalyst and NO more than Mn as shown in Fig. 6. Interestingly, NO-TPD (adsorbed at 60 ℃) showed a similar adsorption amount, but in the DRIFT result measured at 120 ℃, MnSm showed a higher adsorption intensity of NO2 -/NO3 - compared to MnSm5Ce. It is suggested that this is due to the surface and unstable adsorption strength [54], and this result can increase the affinity with the reactants in the gas phase. However, in the case of Mn, the significantly lower NO2 -/NO3 - intensity is confirmed only as a result of the low adsorption amount, as confirmed by the NO-TPD result. Notably, a peak (~1620 cm−1) corresponding to gaseous NO2 was observed in all catalysts. Notably, the addition of Sm and Ce increases the formation of gaseous NO2, which is provided as a factor that can indicate an increase in performance at low temperatures compared to Mn. Specifically, the formation of NO2 via NO oxidation rapidly reacts with NH3 at low temperature, and a 'Fast SCR reaction' might occur. To confirm the experimental results, an NO oxidation experiment was performed, and the results are shown in Fig. S6A. As a result, it was confirmed that the oxidation performance of NO to NO2 was distinguished, especially at temperatures below 200 °C among the Mn based catalysts. In particular, MnSm5Ce showed a high NO to NO2 conversion of ~17% at 150 °C compared to Mn. In other words, this suggested that MnSm5Ce is more likely to undergo a “Fast reaction” at low temperatures. Figs. 7B, 7E, and 7 H show the NH3 adsorption trend after NO/O2 coadsorption of Mn, MnSm, and MnSm5Ce, respectively. When NH3 was injected, an additional peak was confirmed to be formed. The bands at 3372 and 3265 cm−1 were assigned to the symmetric stretching of NH3 coordinated to the Lewis acid site, and those at 1456 and 1407 cm−1 were assigned to the asymmetric vibration of NH4 + bound to the Brӧnsted acid site [55]. However, it is difficult to confirm the exact amount and acidic species because the nitrate species site and the acidic site overlap [56]. As soon as NH3 was injected, the peak at 1620 cm−1 corresponding to gaseous NO2 decreased in all catalysts. In particular, in the case of Mn, it was confirmed that the gaseous NO2 peak was consumed at 10 min after ammonia injection. Meanwhile, it was confirmed that MnSm and MnSm5Ce completely disappeared at 5 min and 2 min, respectively. This means that the addition of Sm and Ce accelerates the reaction between the adsorbed NO2 species and NH3. Notably, it is confirmed that the reaction of NO2 and NH3 was the fastest in MnSm5Ce. On the other hand, it showed that the peak of mono- and bidentate nitrate (NO3 -) was hardly reduced even when NH3 was injected. Notably, even when Sm and Ce were added, it was confirmed that the peaks of mono- and bidentate were slightly reduced. This result suggested that mono- and bidentate nitrate species (NO3 -) have poor reactivity in MnOx-based catalysts. This meant that the reaction trait with NH3 was different depending on the bonding form of NOX species. On the other hand, it was confirmed that the band at 1290 cm−1 corresponding to chelating nitrite (NO2 -) is slightly increased in MnSm and MnSm5Ce [2]. It was suggested that NH4NO2 species are formed. Because the NH4NO2 species decomposed into N2 and H2O, it was suggested to be responsible for the enhanced N2 selectivity. Then, to investigate the type of mechanism, the injection of NO/O2 was started again after blocking ammonia. In all catalysts, the band at ~1620 cm−1 corresponding to gaseous NO2 increased again, and the features of the Brӧnsted acidic site in the 3200–3400 cm−1 region representing the Lewis acid site and the Brӧnsted acidic site in 1400–1460 cm−1 were also slightly reduced. This suggests that all catalysts followed a Langmuir-Hinshelwood and Eley-Rideal mechanism. In other words, all catalysts are proposed to follow a dual-mechanism (i.e., Eley-Rideal and Langmuir-Hinshelwood typed mechanism) at low temperature. In contrast, to confirm the adsorption characteristics at high temperature, the reactants were injected in the same order at 300 °C as shown in Fig. S7. Unlike at 120 °C, the peak of gaseous NO2 (~1620 cm−1) was not observed in all catalysts. Because it interacts weakly with the catalyst surface compared to other nitrate/nitrite (NO3 - or NO2 -) species, it is suggested that it is not observed in adsorption analogues at high temperature. However, the bidentate nitrate species (NO3 -) representing the ~1550–1600 cm−1 region showed adsorbed features in all catalysts. It is suggested to maintain the adsorbed form at high temperature because it is strongly bonded to the catalyst surface by two bonds. Notably, even at 300 °C, MnSm and MnSm5Ce are confirmed to show approximately twice the adsorption amount of nitrate/nitrite (NO3 - or NO2 -) peak intensity compared to Mn. This suggested that the amount of reactive nitrate/nitrite species on Sm or Ce modified catalysts is higher at high temperatures. Interestingly, the band at 1383 cm−1 was observed in MnSm5Ce. It is assigned an NO2 species bound to metal (Mn, Sm, or Ce) [57]. In other words, the nitrite (NO2 -) species follows the intermediate NH4NO2 formation pathway, suggesting that it potentially increases N2 selectivity. After shutting off NO/O2 in the same scheme as 120 °C, NH3 was injected. Interestingly, all nitrate/nitrite species appeared to be desorbed as soon as 2 min in all catalysts at 300 °C. Notably, it appears that Mn hardly has an adsorbed analog of NH3 after NH3 injection. This result suggested that the binding affinity with NH3 on the catalyst surface is reduced because the surface thermal energy of the catalyst is high, or that it is immediately oxidized and desorbed. On the other hand, in the case of MnSm or MnSm5Ce, some Lewis acidic features are visible. It is confirmed that only a part of the strongly bound Lewis acidic site and a part of the very weak Brӧnsted acidic site are adsorbed, and Sm and Ce are suggested to play a partial role in increasing affinity with NH3. After that, when NO/O2 was injected again, it was confirmed that the nitrate/nitrite species increased again. Again, adsorption of nitrate/nitrite species was confirmed to be major, and although introduction of Sm and Ce enhances affinity with NH3, it was highly suggested that all catalysts mainly follow the ‘Eley-Rideal’ typed mechanism at high temperature. Meanwhile, the cause of the decrease in X(NOx) and S(N2) should also be considered. At low temperature, X(NOx) might be reduced due to insufficient thermal energy of the catalyst. NH3 used as a reducing agent does not react with NOX, but reacts with active oxygen on the catalyst surface and is oxidized to NOX species (or N2O) at high temperature. Therefore, the X(NOx) and S(N2) is reduced at a high temperature due to the lack of NH3 as a reducing agent. Therefore, the oxidation reaction characteristics were investigated via in situ DRIFTs by injecting 1000 ppm NH3 and 3 vol% O2 at 120–300 °C were confirmed as shown in Fig. S8. The bands at 1627, 1437, 1378, 1292 and 1260 cm−1 were observed in Mn. The band at 1627 cm−1 was assigned to symmetric bending vibrations of the N–H bonds coordinately linked to Lewis acid sites [58]. The band at 1437 cm−1 corresponding to symmetric bending vibrations of the NH4 + species linked to Brӧnsted acid sites [36]. In all catalysts, the peak intensity tends to decrease as the temperature increases. In other words, the adsorption capacity decreases as the thermal energy of the catalyst surface increases. In the case of Mn, in particular, bands at 1378, 1305, and 1260 cm−1 were observed, unlike MnSm and MnSm5Ce. This corresponds to a mono-dentate nitrate species (NO3 -) formed by the oxidation of the ammonia [59]. At high temperature, NH3 could exhibit side reactions due to oxidation in the presence of oxygen or NOX species on the catalyst surface via Eqs. (8)–(10). (8) 4 NH 3 + 4 O 2 → 2 N 2 O + 6 H 2 O (9) 2 NH 3 + 2 N O 2 → 4 N 2 O + N 2 + 3 H 2 O (10) 4 NH 3 + 4 NO + 3 O 2 → 4 N 2 O + 6 H 2 O In other words, when NH3/O2 is injected in the case of Mn, it suggests that oxidation occurs favorably with the formation of nitrate species. Importantly, this is identified as the cause of the decreased N2 selectivity and NOX conversion in the SCR reaction. Again, NH3 used as a reducing agent is converted to NOX, suggesting that it serves as a cause of reducing X(NOx). To confirm these results experimentally, an NH3 oxidation reaction was performed, and the results are shown in Fig. S6B. It was confirmed that the XNH3 (NH3 conversion) was more than 20% above 200 °C in all catalysts. Notably, MnSm5Ce showed relatively low XNH3 among the Mn based catalysts. NH3 intimacy with the catalyst surface is important for the SCR reaction to proceed. However, when NH3 is oxidized, it cannot act as a reducing agent, so it might adversely affect the SCR reaction. To clearly distinguish the selectivity of each catalyst, selectivity was shown at 220–300 °C (in Fig. S9). In the case of Mn, it was found that NOX and N2O were generated the most above 220 °C, and in particular, it was confirmed that NOX (or N2O) was generated by 10% ≥ 280 °C more than MnSm and MnSm5Ce. It suggested that this occurred because the adsorption of NH3 reacted with oxygen in the catalyst and liberation to NOX (or N2O) occurred favorably. Again, as observed in Fig. S7, NH3 adsorption was observed to be small because NH3 does not remain adsorbed on the catalyst surface but is oxidized to NOX and liberated. Additionally, since the NOX adsorption ability is greater than that of NH3 (via NH3 or NO/O2-DRIFT), the formation and type of an intermediate between NH3 and NOX (e.g., NH4NO2 or NH4NO3) could be important. Meanwhile, in the case of MnSm and MnSm5Ce, although N2O is generated, the N2 selectivity is excellent compared to Mn. In summary, in the case of Mn, since oxidation of NH3 to NOX or N2O species occurs favorably on the catalyst surface, X(NOx) and N2 selectivity is observed to be significantly decreased at high temperature. On the other hand, in the case of MnSm and MnSm5Ce, because the intimacy of the catalyst surface with NH3 was appropriate, it was confirmed that X(NOx) and N2 selectivity was increased. To conduct an in-depth study on the catalyst surface, a kinetic experiment was performed. The rate law (or rate equation) for the SCR reaction is shown below, and the concentration and constant parameters and the forward reaction rate are considered. (11) − r NOX = k [ NO ] α [ NH 3 ] β [ O 2 ] γ where constant k is the reaction rate constant, and [NO], [NH3], and [O2] are the concentrations of the inlet gas (ppm). The exponents of α, β, and γ are reaction orders of [NO], [NH3], and [O2]. In this case, oxygen does not affect the rate because it is in excess relative to the concentration of NO and NH3 and could be canceled (γ = ~0). Meanwhile, it is difficult to confirm a noticeable difference in SCR performance. Because the performance was attributed to the diffusion region, various effects (e.g., amount of NO or NH3 species, binding affinity, gas concentration, etc.). Therefore, to identify the fundamental rate of each catalyst, the kinetic experiment was performed under the same gas conditions as the NH3-SCR performance experiment: NOX 500 ppm, the ratio of NH3/NOX = 1, 8 vol% O2. Additionally, to satisfy the condition of the X(NOx) to ≤ 25% compared to thermodynamic equilibrium conversion (only considering forward reaction) [56,60], the temperature was set to 110–130 °C, and the space velocity was performed under the condition of 600,000 hr−1. The -r NOX value of each catalyst is shown in Fig. 8B-8D. Each -r NOX value was expressed as the number of moles of NO converted per gram of catalysts per unit time. In particular, it was confirmed that MnSm5Ce converted the largest amount of NOX (-r NOX). Meanwhile, a NOX/NH3 concentration variation experiment was performed to confirm the reaction order of the rate law. As a result, it could be confirmed that the catalyst rate according to all NOX concentrations followed the 1st order, and it was confirmed that it showed a value close to zero order according to the NH3 concentration (in Fig. S10A). These results confirm that -r NOX can be changed according to the concentration of NOX (in Fig. S10B). In other words, MnOx-based catalysts suggest that the rate is determined by the concentration of NOX. Arrhenius plots of 1/T (K) vs ln(-r NOX) at 110–130 °C are shown. In this graph, the slope is (-Ea/R) and the y-axis is ln (k APP, 0). The activation energies (Ea) of Mn, MnSm, and MnSm5Ce all showed similar values (~14–15 kJ mol−1). As mentioned above, it seems to have a relatively low activation energy because the rate difference is not large in the reaction conditions in which X(NOx) is ≤ 25% under the wet stream. Remarkably, the collision frequencies showed different trends. In particular, MnSm5Ce showed 24.6 ( ± 2.7) min−1 ppm−1 while Mn showed 13.0 ( ± 3.2) min−1 ppm−1. In summary, since MnSm5Ce has the largest collision frequency of NH3 and NO on the catalyst surface, it is confirmed that the number of moles of NOX converted per unit gram of catalyst is high. These results could be attributed to MnSm5Ce having the number of redox sites (via O2 on/off) and Lewis acidic sites (via XPS or NH3-TPD) per gram catalyst. 3.5 Sulfated catalysts MnOx-based catalysts are severely poisoned by the formation of metal sulfate (e.g., MnSO4 acting as an inactive site) in a feed gas stream containing SO2. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate the SO2 effect. To evaluate the SCR performance of the catalyst exposed to SO2, 100 ppm of SO2 was injected for an hour before the experiment, and then performance evaluation was performed in the same flow stream as the SCR performance as shown in Fig. S10. Interestingly, the X(NOx) and N2 selectivity of all catalysts was enhanced above 200 °C. On the other hand, below 200 °C, the low temperature performance of Mn and MnSm tended to decrease by more than 5%. However, in the case of MnSm5Ce, even when exposed to 100 ppm SO2, it was confirmed that X(NOx) was similar to the initial performance. To confirm the changed properties of the catalyst exposed to SO2, XRD analysis was performed to determine whether a major structural change occurred as shown in Fig. S12A. Here, the catalyst exposed to 100 ppm of SO2 for an hour was expressed as “XXX-S (pristine MnOx-based catalysts denoted XXX). As before exposure to SO2, only the anatase peak of TiO2 was observed in the bulk catalyst. On the other hand, it is confirmed that the formation of MnSO4 formed by exposure to SO2 was not observed in the XRD pattern, which might be highly dispersed on the catalyst surface and existed in an amorphous form. Therefore, to investigate structural traits, TEM analysis was performed as shown in Fig. S11B-G. In the TEM images, there was no discernible difference in all catalysts exposed to SO2, similar to the XRD results. Therefore, SAED pattern analysis was performed to confirm the structural trait as shown in Fig. S12C, E, and G. When Mn was exposed to SO2, it was confirmed that the (002) facet of MnSO4 (JCPDF No. of 00–003–0810) was formed. The positions of metal oxide were confirmed through EDX analysis as shown in Fig. S13. Notably, Mn and S element are highly dispersed at the same location on the TiO2 surface. This might indicate the formation of MnSO4 as in the SAED pattern analysis result. We confirmed how the introduction of Sm affects the affinity between Mn and SO2. It was confirmed that the (002) facet of MnSO4 was exhibited in the same manner as Mn, but the characteristic of (111) facet of SmSO4 (JCPDF No. of 00–017–0775) was also observed. This could be suggested when exposed to SO2, as some of the SO2 is adsorbed to the Sm site. Additionally, when EDX mapping was confirmed, Mn (yellow dot) and Sm (blue dot) seemed to be located in the same place, and it was confirmed that S was located relatively little in the part where Sm and Mn were mainly located. It is suggested that the affinity with S is partially reduced due to the interaction between Mn and Sm. Again, this could suggest that the formation of MnSO4 acting as an inactive site in the catalyst exposed to SO2 can be inhibited. Meanwhile, in MnSm5Ce, the (002) facet of MnSO4 and (111) facet of SmSO4 and the (022) facet of Ce2(SO4)3 (JCPDF No. of 00–052–1494) were confirmed in the case of the catalyst exposed to SO2. In other words, the introduction of Sm and Ce might reduce some of the formation of MnSO4. Interestingly, as a result of EDX mapping, it is confirmed that S (orange color) is present in a position similar to Ce, and when compared with a place where Mn was clearly shown, while it is confirmed that S is partially present. This suggested that it might exist mainly in the form of Ce2(SO4)3 rather than MnSO4, and for this reason, the performance reduction at low temperature could be suppressed. Since Ce2(SO4)3 acted as an additional acidic site, the formation of MnSO4 is inhibited and could act as a performance enhancing effect. In summary, Sm and Ce inhibited the interaction between Mn and SO2, indicating structural change from MnO2, which can be provided as a major active site. Additionally, the introduction of Ce plays a role in helping the formation of Ce2(SO4)3, which could be provided as an additional active site and has resistance to performance reduction [61,62]. Meanwhile, in-situ DRIFT spectroscopy was performed to investigate the effect of the formation of metal sulfate species on the performance at high temperatures in MnOx based catalysts. Therefore, the surface properties of the Mn-based catalyst (pristine or sulfation) were confirmed by injection of NH3 and NO at 300 °C. In-situ DRIFT spectroscopy was expressed by injection in the order of 1000 ppm NH3 → 1000 ppm NH3/8 vol% O2 → 1000 ppm NO/8 vol. O2. First, only NH3 was injected to confirm whether NH3 was adsorbed only as a reducing agent to the metal oxide surface, and then NH3/O2 was injected to check the oxidation ability of NH3 (to see the undesired reaction). Afterwards, NO/O2 was injected to confirm the reaction and interaction ability and mechanism with NO. NH3 was injected into the pristine catalysts, and the bands at 3354, 3280, 3176, 1723, 1608, 1433, and 1319 cm−1 were observed, as shown in Fig. 9. The bands at 3354, 3280, and 3176 cm−1 were assigned to the N-H symmetric stretching vibration mode of NH3 coordinated to Lewis acidic site. The bands at 1723 and 1433 cm−1 could be assigned to asymmetric stretching and bending vibrations of N-H bonds adsorbed on Brӧnsted acid site. The bands at 1608 and 1319 cm−1 could be ascribed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of N-H linked to Lewis acid site and the vibration of N-H linked to Lewis acid sites [3]. In the pristine catalysts, MnSm5Ce showed a large amount of NH3 to the Lewis acid site, and Mn showed the lowest interaction with NH3. After that, O2 was additionally injected. Notably, the peaks of the bands at 1642 and 1496 cm−1 were largely observed in only Mn [53]. In particular, the band at 1642 cm−1 showed a peak even when only NH3 was injected. It is assigned as bridged nitrate (NO3 -) [63] and could be a nitrate species formed by oxidation by an oxygen source on the catalyst surface. In other words, in the case of Mn, the adsorption of NH3 suggested the possibility of NH3 direct oxidation to NOX. Meanwhile, the band at 1496 cm−1 could be assigned as a bidentate nitrate species. Again, a side reaction by NH3 could occur with the formation of nitrate species (NO, NO2, or N2O). Except for Mn, in MnSm and MnSm5Ce, peaks were not observed except for the decrease in intensity. Then, the analogues were expressed after injection of NO/O2 for 30 min. After NO/O2 injection for 30 min, the new bands at 1741, 1631, 1496, 1378 and 1254 cm−1 were observed. Interestingly, bands at 1741 and 1496 cm−1 were observed only on the Mn surface. The band at 1741 cm−1 could be assigned to N2O4 species [64]. As in Eq 18, N2O4 could form an intermediate of NH4NO3 or NH4NO2, in particular, NH4NO3 species decomposed to N2O and H2O. In addition, it was confirmed that the stable form of bidentate nitrate (1496 cm−1) was largely observed, and the band at 1254 cm−1 corresponding to NH4NO3 was observed [53,64]. However, in the case of MnSm and MnSm5Ce, the bands at 1741 cm−1 (N2O4 species) and bidentate nitrate were not observed, while bands at 1631 and 1378 cm−1 were observed, indicating bridged nitrate and monodentate nitrate, respectively [64,65]. These were relatively adsorbed more unstably than the bidentate species [66]. Fig. 9B shows the in-situ DRIFT of the sulfated catalyst. Notably, in the case of the Mn catalyst, the intensity of acidic sites was significantly reduced after sulfation. This result suggested that NH3 was difficult to participate in the reaction or was rapidly oxidized to the form of nitrate/nitrite, so it is difficult to detect adsorbed species because the oxidized nitrate/nitrite species could be converted to nitrogen by reacting with adsorbed NH3. This shows a result similar to that of Fig. S7. After that, when O2 was injected, it was confirmed that the overall adsorption intensity was reduced similar to that of the pristine sample. Subsequently, in the case of Mn after NO/O2 injection, it was confirmed that some of the Lewis acid sites were observed above 3000 cm−1, and nitrate/nitrite species were not significantly observed. In other words, the sulfation treated Mn increased the N2 selectivity by inhibiting the formation of nitrate species or NH4NO3. However, this result suggested that X(NOx) and S(N2) are the lowest among the Mn based catalysts due to the decrease in affinity of NO and NH3. On the other hand, in the case of MnSm and MnSm5Ce, the adsorption of NH3 and NO was maintained similar to that of pristine, rather, it is suggested that the N2 selectivity was enhanced by the adsorption of bridged nitrate/monodentate nitrate. For pristine catalysts, all catalysts are proposed as Eley-Rideal and Langmuir-Hinshelwood type mechanism. However, in the case of Mn after sulfation, it is suggested to be the Eley-Rideal mechanism in which NH3 is mainly adsorbed. In summary, the formation of intermediate species affects the X(NOx) and N2 selectivity. The adsorption of reactive gases and the formation of intermediate species on the surface of each catalyst were investigated via in-situ DRIFT analysis. Therefore, the following possible SCR reaction pathway was proposed. (12) M n + − NH 3 ads → dehydrogenation M ( n − 1 ) + − NH 2 ads (13) M ( n − 1 ) + − NH 2 ads + NO g → M n − 1 + − NH 2 NO ads → M n − 1 + + N 2 + H 2 O (14) M ( n − 1 ) + − NH 2 ads + 2 O 2 → M n − 1 + − NO 3 ads + H 2 O (15) M n − 1 + − OH + NH 3 g → M n − 1 + − OH ⋯ NH 3 ads → M n − 1 + − O ⋯ NH 4 + (16) NO 3 − + NH 4 + → NH 4 NO 3 ( ads ) → N 2 O ( g ) + 2 H 2 O ( g ) (17) M n + = O + NO ( g ) → M ( n − 1 ) + − O − NO ads (18) 2 NO 2 ( ads ) → N 2 O 4 ( ads ) → H 2 O HNO 3 ads + HNO 2 ads → 2 NH 3 NH 4 NO 3 ( ads ) + NH 4 NO 2 ( ads ) (19) NH 4 NO 3 ( ads ) → N 2 O ( g ) + 2 H 2 O ( g ) (20) NH 4 NO 2 ( ads ) → N 2 ( g ) + 2 H 2 O ( g ) In Eq. (12), gaseous NH3 is adsorbed to the Lewis acidic site, and it is oxidized or dehydrogenated by oxygen species near the Mn+ site (Lewis acidic site, M= Mn, Sm, or Ce) (as shown in the NH3 adsorption step of Fig. 9A) [64,67]. Mn(n−1)+-NH2 reacts with gaseous NO to form NH2NO intermediate species, and is then converted to N2 and H2O (Eq. (13)). Additionally, it reacts with Oα (or gaseous oxygen) to form NO3 - (bidentate nitrate) and H2O (Eq. (14), as shown in the NH3/O2 adsorption step of Fig. 9A). Meanwhile, NH3 is adsorbed to Mn(n−1)+-OH (Brӧnsted acidic site) to form NH4 + (Eq. (15)). The formed nitrate species and NH4 + react to form NH4NO3 intermediate species, and N2O and H2O are formed (Eq. (16)) [59,68]. In other words, the formation of NH4NO3 could have the effect of lowering the N2 selectivity at high temperatures. On the other hand, NO in the gas phase could be adsorbed to Mn+=O (redox site) to form NO2. NO2 reacts with nearby NO2 to form N2O4 by the double connection of NO2 (as shown in the NO/O2 adsorption step of Fig. 9A) [68]. N2O4 species HNO3 and HNO2 were formed by chemisorbed H2O (e.g., O′α via XPS) or injected H2O in a feed stream, and reacted with adsorbed NH3 or gaseous NH3 to form NH4NO3 or NH4NO2 [64]. It was converted to N2O and H2O or N2 and 2 H2O, respectively. In summary, the formation of NH4NO3, which is an intermediate species, could be a pathway to lower the N2 selectivity at high temperatures. In particular, since the formation of N2O4 could proceed to the N2O formation pathway, it could lower X(NOx) and S(N2). As expressed in the in-situ DRIFTS analysis, in the case of Mn, the formation of N2O4 (the band at 1741 cm−1) was observed to be major, which might be the cause of the significantly lower selectivity compared to MnSm or MnSm5Ce. In the supporting information, NH3 could be adsorbed to the redox site in addition to the acidic site (Eq. (S1)). NH3 is adsorbed to Mn+=O (redox site) and NH3 is oxidized to M(n−1)+-OH and NH2. It can react with gaseous NO or adsorbed NO on the surface to form NH2NO intermediate species and is converted to N2 and H2O [69]. In addition, NH2 adsorbed to the redox site (or Lewis acidic site) reacts with gaseous O2 or surface oxygen species to form nitrate/nitrite species (Eqs. (S3) and (S4)). It reacts with NH4 + to convert to N2O and H2O. Meanwhile, NO and 1/2 O2 are adsorbed to Mn+=O (redox site) to form nitrate/nitrite. The nitrate species reacted with nearby NO to form NO2. However, nitrite species can be converted to N2 and H2O by reacting with NH3 (Eqs. (S7)-(S9)). Notably, 2(Mn+=O) (redox site) could react with NO to form oxygen vacancies (OV) while forming NO2. Here, OV could be restored by gaseous oxygen. The N2O4 formed an intermediate species NH4NO3/NH4NO2 as described above, and a decomposition reaction proceeded. That is, it suggested that the formation of N2O4/NH4NO3 at the redox site (or at the acidic site) had a major effect on X(NOx) and S(N2). Therefore, the introduction of Sm and SmCe inhibited the formation of bidentate nitrate species and N2O4 while forming monodentate/bridged nitrate species. In particular, the introduction of Ce could increase the performance and selectivity at high temperature by increasing the affinity of NH3 and NO even after sulfation. In summary, referring to Fig. 9 and Eqs. (12)-(20), NO2 and N2O4 (intermediate species) formed by the reaction of reactive oxygen and NO could additionally form NH4NO3 species. The formation of these intermediate species reduces NOx reduction performance and N2 selectivity. That is, improving the catalytic performance could be achieved by changing the surface reaction mechanism through (1) the introduction of Sm or SmCe, and (2) sulfation treatment. In other words, the above two methods can increase the N2 selectivity by inhibiting the formation of N2O4 and the formation of bidentate nitrate species. 3.6 Resistance to SO2/O2 of the catalysts As mentioned in the introduction, the MnOx-based catalysts are known to be very vulnerable to SCR performance. Therefore, SO2 longevity evaluation was performed in the feed stream containing SO2 of the prepared MnOx based catalyst as shown in Fig. 10 A. To confirm resistance to only SO2, X(NOx) was measured at 200 °C with a condition excluding NH3 slip and a space velocity of 30,000 hr−1 to meet the condition for X(NOx) by ~100%. The concentration of SO2 was injected to 100 ppm, a condition similar to that previously reported elsewhere [35,41,70]. When NH3 slip occurs, ammonium sulfate is formed by reacting with H2O/SO2 present in the feed gas stream, and the resistance to only H2O of the catalysts could not be compared by side reaction. The initial X(NOx) of the Mn based catalysts was approximately 100%, and the S(N2) in the reaction also showed ~100%. The SO2 resistance was compared based on the time when X(NOx) was ~ 60%. As a result, the SO2 resistance of Mn, MnSm, and MnSm5Ce was 6.8 hr, 9.1 hr, and 11.5 hr, respectively. In the case of Mn, the performance decreased as soon as SO2 was injected, and in the case of MnSm5Ce, it was confirmed that the performance decreased from approximately 7 hr. In the case of MnSm and MnSm5Ce, the performance is maintained for a certain time as the formation of MnSO4 is delayed due to the formation of SmSO4 or Ce2(SO4)3, respectively. In-situ DRIFT spectroscopy was performed to investigate the surface properties of the catalysts. Experimental environments were carried out under the same temperature conditions as those of the SO2 resistance experiment. To observe the change in surface properties according to the SO2 injection, the before and after SO2 injection were compared for each catalyst, and are shown in Fig. S14. Before SO2 injection, NO, NH3, O2, and H2O were injected to make the SCR conditions the same. As a result, bands at 3235, 3057, and 1294 cm−1 were observed before SO2 injection (closed circles) in all catalysts. The blue dashed squares are Brӧnsted acidic sites, and 3235, 3057, and 1294 cm−1 vibrations are assigned to Lewis acidic sites. Notably, it was confirmed that the intensity of the Brӧnsted acidic site and the peak of 1403 cm−1 in 'Mn' were greatly increased after SO2 injection. Brӧnsted acidic sites were increased due to the increase in NH4 + of ammonium bisulfate (ABS), and 1403 cm−1 was assigned to the peak due to the formation of ABS. In other words, in the case of 'Mn', it could be confirmed that the formation of ABS on the catalyst surface favorably appeared as the increase in vibration caused by the Brӧnsted acidic site and ABS formation after SO2 injection. On the other hand, in the case of Sm and Ce-modified MnOx/TiO2, it was confirmed that there was no significant change in the peak after SO2 injection. Therefore, it could be suggested that the introduction of Sm and Ce suppressed the deactivation (ABS formation) of MnOx/TiO2. TGA-MASS analysis was performed to confirm the deactivated source of each catalyst in detail. To make a clear comparison of the weight losses of the catalysts, the deactivated catalysts were exposed at 200 °C under a stream of SO2/O2/NH3/NO/H2O for 40 hr to prepare samples. According to TGA analysis, the weight loss of Mn, MnSm, and MnSm5Ce were 30.2 wt%, 20.8 wt%, 18.3 wt%, respectively as shown in Fig. 10B. That is, Mn exhibited the largest amount of poisoning by SO2. As with the result of EDX mapping results, it could be seen that the intimacy by SO2 on the surface was the largest. The decomposition profile of the deactivation catalyst was confirmed and is shown in Fig. 10 C. All catalysts were divided into 3 stages (~300 °C, ~500 °C, and ≥ 600 °C) on weight decrease. The weight loss of stage I was caused by evaporation of physisorbed or chemisorbed H2O, and all of them showed similar weight loss [68]. Stage II could be assigned as (NH4)2SO4 (AS) and/or NH4HSO4 (ABS) decomposition [71]. Notably, a significant difference in weight loss was observed for each catalyst in stage II. This indicated that the introduction of Sm and/or Ce suppressed the formation of AS or ABS by reducing affinity with SO2. In particular, it was confirmed that the introduction of Ce resulted in a significant reduction in weight loss, which is suggested by the favorable formation of cerium sulfate (Ce2(SO4)3 species) and inhibiting the formation of AS/ABS of Mn based catalysts. Stage III was reported to be caused by the decomposition of metal sulfate species (e.g., MnSO4, SmSO4, and/or Ce2(SO4)3) [8,64,72]. Meanwhile, to closely confirm the decomposition product, the product according to the pyrolysis of poisoned catalysts was investigated as shown in Fig. S15. It was possible to confirm the product liberated at a similar stage as in the previously reported literature [61,73,74]. In stage I, NH3 and H2O were liberated, which is a source attributable to physisorbed or chemisorbed H2O, and is identified as NH3 partially decomposed from ammonium sulfate. Stage II is suggested to be NH3 and H2O following the decomposition of AS/ABS. This is suggested as a stage where H2O is liberated from (NH4)HSO4 and (NH4)2S2O7 is formed, as shown in the following equation. It is also suggested that NH3 is liberated from the decomposition of AS. In Stage III, NH3 and H2O were partially adsorbed on the catalyst surface after AS/ABS decomposition. In addition, this result suggested that NH3 and H2O were liberated as (NH4)2S2O7 decomposed. In addition, as in the previously reported literature, above 600 ℃, it is suggested that SO2 emitted as metal sulfates are decomposed. (21) ( N H 4 ) 2 S O 4 → N H 4 H S O 4 + N H 3 (22) 2 N H 4 H S O 4 → ( N H 4 ) 2 S 2 O 7 + H 2 O (23) 3 ( N H 4 ) 2 S 2 O 7 → 2 N H 3 + 6 S O 2 + 2 N 2 + 9 H 2 O As seen from the trend curve, it is confirmed that the slope of Mn is the largest, which was confirmed due to the formation of a large amount of MnSO4. Meanwhile, in the case of MnSm and MnSm5Ce, it is suggested that SmSO4 or Ce2(SO4)3 is formed to show a moderate slope compared to Mn, respectively. In summary, it was confirmed that Sm has some effect of resistance to SO2 on MnOx-based catalysts, and MnSm5Ce enhanced the durability to SO2 by inhibiting the formation of MnSO4, and promoting the formation of SmSO4 and Ce2(SO4)3 providing additional acidic sites. 4 Conclusions In this study, the introduction of Sm and Ce in MnOx/TiO2 was investigated for changes in catalyst surface properties and performance. The introduction of 3 wt% Sm was a factor that could lead to an increase in defective Mnn+ sites and redox traits. In addition, the introduction of Ce into ‘MnSm’ helped increase the amount of reducible oxygen and acidic sites of the bulk catalyst. Especially in the ‘MnSm’, 5 wt% Ce not only increased the ability to reduce oxygen to the lowest thermal energy, but also significantly increased the ratio of surface-chemisorbed oxygen. In particular, the introduction of Sm and Ce in the low-temperature region favorably formed gaseous NO2 species on the catalyst surface. Meanwhile, pristine MnOx based catalysts have been proposed as a dual mechanism in which the Eley-Rideal and Langmuir Hinshelwood type mechanisms simultaneously proceed at low temperature. The activation energy of the Mn-based catalyst was similar, but ‘MnSm5Ce’ was confirmed to have the highest prefactor. Meanwhile, when ‘Mn’ and ‘MnSm’ were exposed to SO2/O2, NOx reduction was greatly reduced, but the X(NOx) of ‘MnSm5Ce’ was maintained at low temperature. Interestingly, the formation of N2O4 intermediate species was only observed in ‘Mn’, and the adsorption of bidentate nitrate (NO3 -) species was mainly observed. The formed N2O4 species forms NH4NO3, suggesting that the N2O formation pathway proceeds. On the other hand, the introduction of Sm and Ce suppressed the formation of N2O4. However, when exposed to SO2/O2, the adsorption capacity of ‘Mn’ was significantly reduced. In particular, ‘MnSm5Ce’ maintained its adsorption capacity compared to ‘Mn’ and MnSm even when exposed to SO2/O2. The SO2 longevity test was further investigated. The introduction of Sm increases the resistance to SO2 by reducing the affinity between Mn and SO2. In addition, introduction of Ce suppressed the adsorption to SO2, thereby greatly increasing the resistance to SO2. This study clarified the reason why the introduction of Sm and Ce improved the SCR performance and durability to SO2, and the reason for the enhancement of X(NOx) and N2 selectivity was investigated through surface property analysis and mechanism study. coredata.dc:description: The MnOx/TiO2-based NOX reduction catalyst showed moderate performance at low temperature and had the disadvantage of low N2 selectivity. Herein, the effect of Sm and Ce interactions on MnOx-based catalysts in selective catalytic reduction was investigated. Sm increased the redox properties of the MnOx catalyst and the ratio of Mn4+. Meanwhile, Ce enhanced the additional redox trait of the Sm-modified catalyst. When exposed to SO2/O2, Sm and Ce-modified MnOx not only suppressed performance degradation, but also increased N2 selectivity. Sm and Ce suppress the formation of N2O by inhibiting the formation of N2O4 intermediate species. Additionally, regardless of exposure to SO2/O2, Sm/Ce modified MnOx is an LH-ER mechanism (Langmuir-Hinshelwood and Eley-Rideal mechanism), but in the case of MnOx, it is suggested to be mainly an ER mechanism when exposed to SO2/O2. From these results, a strategy for improving the N2 selectivity/SCR performance of MnOx/TiO2-based catalysts with SO2 resistance was provided.
coredata.dc:title: Surface insights into MnOx-based catalysts containing metal oxides for the selective catalytic reduction of NOX with NH3
